body:
Is it possible to add a text message below the spinner?
Naive approach didn't work.

what do you mean exactly?

you have every option html and css offers you. there is no "native" option given by SpinKit.
Here are two examples adding text below: https://jsfiddle.net/v02f6to7/
if you want the text also to be spinning or attached to the animation you first have to look at the animation css itself and decide if you add extra html / text in the spinner element itself or if pseudo elements are an option.

hope i could help you.
this isn't an issue, more an faq request. should be closed.
Thanks.

Is this possible? I've been mucking around with jQuery and CSS for the last hour or two trying to figure this out, probably something really simple, lol.

which spinner do you mean?
just define a background to the element the spinner depends on.
for example: 'rotating-plane' https://jsfiddle.net/y7yqusgr/
if you want to use the spinner as alpha mask, for example on the "cubemove" one, you could create svg masks and animate them with javascript.
there are some libs such as https://greensock.com/gsap to accomplish that.
i haven't found a way to animate svg mask using css only yet. don't even know if this is possible.

- Bumped version
- Added more precision to animation seconds (2.0s instead of 2s).

Enables importing them easily through the use of eg. https://www.npmjs.com/package/sass-module-importer

With that module one would simply do `@import "spinkit";` and get all of the files or do `@import "spinkit/scss/spinners/1-rotating-plane";` to import a specific spinner, all without having to know exactly where npm put the module, which if Spinkit is a sub-dependency of another package will be hard due to npm 3:s flattening of the dependency tree.

I'm looking to integrate this library into [angular-base-apps](https://github.com/base-apps/angular-base-apps) to provide a set of angular directives for loading symbols.  I want to allow the user to easily change the size and color of the loading symbols as desired.

I noticed PR https://github.com/tobiasahlin/SpinKit/pull/113 attempts to add the ability to configure the size of the loading symbol, however, it still hardcodes the values and produces a ton more CSS that most people will need.

I was wondering whether there were any plans to add SCSS mixins for the spinners?  This would make it possible for the spinner to work with any size configuration as you will simply need to define the math using the argument instead of hard coding the values.
@tobiasahlin I converted the first spinner to use mixins.  Let me know if you like this approach and I'll continue with the rest of them.

I added mixins for all the spinners.  It was fairly straight forward since the scss logic was already broken down to use variables.  I also added the ability to disable css exporting, so that the library can be used only for the mixins without exporting spinkit specific css classes.
@tobiasahlin fyi this will be part of [Angular Base Apps 2.0](https://base-apps.github.io/angular-base-apps/latest/#!/loader) if you're wondering how these changes will be utilized

- Added a simple JS and JQuery plugin that allows the creation and
  removal of a spinner to a DOM element.
- Added Minified Spinkit CSS
- Included Example fields for JS and JQuery usage
I tried to increase the width and height but that's not help me to increase the spinner.
@rajasimon Try this PR https://github.com/tobiasahlin/SpinKit/pull/113
@rajasimon I added scss mixins with PR #121, so you can customize the size to anything you want

Hello,

this is my very first trial on Sass and one of the first for front-end stuff, so, any feedback would be helpful.

From what I see, the implemented animation is not as rapidly evolved as the rest of the existing ones, but I thought of having an overall feedback, as a first step.

TB

Examples:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

There are some breaking changes that allow us to decrease code duplication:
- The class ‚Äúsk‚Äù has to be added to each spinner
- No margin is added to the spinner by default. The classes `sk-auto-hmargin` and `sk-md-vmargin` can be added to revert to the margins used before this PR.
- Renamed `sk-spinner-pulse` to `sk-pulse` to follow naming convention.
- Default to `display: inline-block` and `vertical-align: middle` for a more useful default

All spinners work great to resize except for `4-wandering-cubes`. This is because an absolute size is declared in its keyframe. It would be awesome if anyone could help me come up with a solution to this issue üòÄ

Use currentColor as background-color to inherit current font color
Use relative sizes to inherit current font size

[http://tobiasahlin.com/spinkit/](http://tobiasahlin.com/spinkit/);

this site is very beautiful ,do you tell me the use the frame's name?

I don't know if that's the original meaning of the issue...

But indeed, when I look at the demo and see a nice animation, I would like to know which one to include.
For example, I see the fourth animation. First, I have to count the dots to have the number. It could be displayed somewhere. Second, I don't see the animation name. If I view the source, I see `sk-cubemove` inside it, but this name is nowhere to be found in the `scss/spinners` directory (looks like the demo is a bit out to date?).

So, in short, it would be nice to display "4-wandering-cubes" (in this example) somewhere on the page when selecting a demo.

Thanks.

http://codepen.io/anon/pen/epaNzg

Put your spinner into table and see this artefacts.

@maliyshock Thanks for reporting :pray: Not really sure what's going on here. This is 1) Not an issue in Safari (only Chrome), 2) much less prominent outside of codepen for me, and 3) something I was unable to fix by changing the `display` property for the container, or by playing around with adding transforms (e.g. `transform: translateY(0)`) to any of the elements involved.

As far as I can tell, however, this is not an issue with SpinKit, but with how Chrome handles animations within tables, and how the spinner is being used. Closing for now.

The MIT license requires including the copyright notice and license with the software, yet I don't see that included in the actual files.  Do you expect others to add it when they use your software? (or maybe you might want to add it, so it is always included :)

Thanks.
Hi @jlovejoy! The license file itself should be included, as it's part of the software. I noticed that the copyright year was outdated though, so took the time to update that. Thank you! :boom:
Added a new spinner and added "spinners/11-folding-cube" to spinkit.scss.
@evgenyo :bow: thanks for this! There's a lot of diffs here that are just indentation changes, could you look at cleaning that up? :heart:

@tobiasahlin I believe  https://github.com/tobiasahlin/SpinKit/commit/d45b25cf9f63c8c5fe7c1115ab2f921bc924319b commit never applied the "easier to copy" fix to the HTML/CSS examples, so it's not indentations but removed stars. And since 11-folding-cube was never added to spingkit.scss before, it's added in spinkit.css in this fork as well.
@evgenyo Sorry about that :bow: my fault! Would you mind updating from `master` now? Fixed this, so your PR should be all clean and tidy once you merge in :sparkles::ok_hand:
@tobiasahlin No worries! Should be all fixed up :)

@evgenyo Thanks! :pray: This is looking smooth‚Ä¶¬†wondering though if it can become even smoother. The blinking (fading in/out) is throwing me off a bit, maybe it'd look better if all the circles were hidden/shown through moving and/or scaling? Thinking out loud here, sorry if I'm not making any sense, but I feel like the dots are behaving in two very different ways. Would be great to make their animation patterns more consistent :) relying only on translation and scale could be a way to achieve that.

@tobiasahlin Hello hello! I actually messed around with scale vs opacity, and personally preferred the blinking effect over shrinking because it gave me a loading vibe rather than just a pretty animation. Having said that, it's your project so you tell me what works with your vision best. I also changed the left/top/right/bottom movements to transform:translate as well. Let me know if there's anything else : )

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
@JobaDiniz Thank you for reporting! :bow: Totally agree, will fix.

The current `main` is the gulpfile. However, there are dependencies specified as devDependencies, which breaks Browserify's bundle function because it can't find modules that are required.

I believe the solution should be to remove `gulpfile.js` as the main file in package.json, because users aren't going to use the gulpfile from this project outside of developing.

I'm not quite sure how the CSS files have `-webkit-animation` prefixes, but looking at the code the SCSS variant doesn't.

I'm importing SpinKit into my SASS project via `@import 'spinkit';` however nothing is animating in webkit because of the missing prefix :cry:

You need to use [autoprefixer](https://github.com/postcss/autoprefixer) in your project. If you're compiling your SCSS with gulp you can use [gulp-autoprefixer](https://github.com/sindresorhus/gulp-autoprefixer) or if you use grunt then [grunt-autoprefixer](https://github.com/nDmitry/grunt-autoprefixer). Hello,

I believe everything is in order now.

-Ruben

You need to [pull data from the upstream master](https://help.github.com/articles/syncing-a-fork/) (i.e. `tobiasahlin/SpinKit`) so that we don't get any merge conflicts.

(My recommendation is to always create a new branch when you want to submit a new PR. Github even gives you a notification on your page about sending a PR if you do it this way.)

Hmm, I did pull data from upstream just this afternoon! That's what the second commit, `5c781a5`, does (should have been more clear, my bad). Should I try pulling again?

Apologies for the issues, this is one of my first contributions.

@rubencodes Hi dude,
I'm having problems with updating my project to use the newer format. Would you please help me by explaining the steps which you took to update yours?
@rubencodes No worries. What you need to do is a rebase. GitHub has an [excellent article](https://github.com/edx/edx-platform/wiki/How-to-Rebase-a-Pull-Request) on this.

Actually in this case I think the best thing to do would be to just create a new branch and checkout the scss-files like below. I've made the assumption that you called the `tobiasahlin/SpinKit` upstream `upstream`.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Some notes:
- I didn't include your changes to `9-wordpress.scss` as this should be in a separate PR.
- Use `$spinkit-spinner-margin` and `$spinkit-spinner-color` variables (see the other spinners for where to add)
- Remove all browser prefixes (`-webkit-` etc) as this is now [handled by autoprefixer](https://github.com/tobiasahlin/SpinKit/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- Follow style guide in `CONTRIBUTING.md`

Other than that I really like this contribution! Could see myself using this spinner :blush:

Just go the next slide (circle) and go back to previous one (square).

You'll see that the square is not animating anymore. But if you inspect the item you'll see that the div is "rotating" but not repainting.

A bug?

Tested on Chrome 38.0.2125.122 (Build 290379) m 64bit
Confirmed. @tobiasahlin Do you have any idea what to do about this?

Looks like visibility property for '#spinners li' connected with this issue. It works fine after removing this property from code. I know that switching between visibility's values cause repaint, but I can't explain why it's so important only for the first slide only. And I see that it's not connected with type of animation. We can put any of them to the first slide and it won't work too.
@Invulner Thanks for investigating! Would you mind opening a PR? :heart:

CSS animations are becoming more feasible by the day, with [88.04% coverage according to caniuse.com](http://caniuse.com/#feat=css-animation) I'm thinking that maybe this will just introduce complexity into the project. Being CSS only is a big part of what makes me love this project :heart:

I love your style so I'm thinking of a little commission.

The three bounce is perfect for route transitions, but there are moments in certain views where a component is only fully constructed on demand. Suppose it takes a few seconds, up to six in my case, to build the component; I would like to overlay a spinner that conveys the work of "unboxing" (which the user prefers over "construction" in data entry apps).

The animation would begin with a plain square that unfolds from the centre into a diamond, which then unfolds from the centre into a square. If possible the shape would continuously shrink, and the shape would always be the same size, but if that's too difficult then the larger diamond could scale down before unfolding, and the larger square could scale down before the animation repeated. A simpler version of all this is to simply rotate the diamond back to the square and repeat, but I think the full version is more compelling.

This (or something like it) would make a nice addition to the SpinKit collection :D

![unboxing](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/889388/3495941/57c6e4e8-05dd-11e4-85b5-09cfbcbcd3d6.png)

First of all this spinner kit is awesome and I want to thank you very much.

This is a subset of spinners that I have combined into a single scss file which has been tested and is in full use at my company. This is intended as a starting file to work towards so that the css can be compiled down to a dist/spin-kit.css as the end goal.

Therefore, this is not meant to be a finished peace but is intended as a starting point as a discussion on how you want to proceed. I am fully open to adding a build framework to compile this scss down for you so it can be in separate encapsulated files like wave.scss, and three-bounce.scss. Personally I would favor npm/Grunt or Rails but it is up to you.

I'd love to help contribute.

@nmccready Thanks for starting this discussion :honeybee: I'm a bit torn. I see SpinKit more as a sandbox from which you can grab some CSS and customize it for your site, not a framework. I'm not sure how well this aligns with that, and if the added complexity here adds enough value. What are your thoughts?
Cool, I am not really trying to force a framework here. I am just trying to make it easily importable CSS or SASS.

@tobiasahlin if you look at my code you'll see that I've added:
1. Variables
2. Separated each spinner into it's own SCSS file. This enables you to easily include just the styles you want, without touching the source code at all.
3. Removed all browser prefixes and let autoprefixer take care of this to decrease the risk of typos (and potentially reduce the file size of the generated CSS as browsers start to drop prefixes)
4. The gulp tasks auto-generate the example HTML whenever the code changes

Sure we can go with this PR instead, but like it says it's a starting point whilst #50 is basically good to merge and put in production.

Thanks for the contribution! Although technically very interesting, animating the border-width triggers a redraw every single frame (turn on paint rectangles in Chrome and you'll constantly see the red frame):

![screen shot 2013-12-23 at 20 26 43](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/211284/1802716/929c3cf4-6c08-11e3-9d22-a58e902d1542.png)

Which makes it not as smooth as the other spinners. All the current spinners are limited to animating the `opacity` as well as the `transform` properties. This spinner is also quite geometrically complex compared to other spinners‚ÄîI'd like to keep it simple, so I'll close this for now :sparkles:

:warning:  This fixes a quite critical bug.

I've heard of spinners not animating for some in Chrome. They've been working fine for me, and it doesn't seem to be dependent on your setup/Chrome version. I haven't been able to figure out why this is happening, but I've figured out how to fix it.

The problem seems to be that Chrome supports `@keyframes` definitions without the `-webkit` prefix. Chrome doesn't, however, support `transform` without the `-webkit-` prefix. So even though `@-webkit-keyframes` is defined, `@keyframes` takes precedence, and nothing animates. This PR adds `-webkit-` to all transformations inside all `@keyframes` blocks.

(What makes no sense is that if this really is the case, it should never have worked in Chrome.)

That is not _SpinKit_'s fault. IE9 does not support animations. You will need IE10+.

@nits What @sahat is saying is true. SpinKit's goal isn't to offer a solution that works in every browser, but to use CSS animations in browsers that supports them to create smooth and easily customizable animations.

If you want to use this for a project where you have users running IE9 and below, you'll want to check for unsupported browsers with JS and replace the spinner with a gif (or something similar.)
